original_title: Sri  Lanka wants regulate, tax and license private tuition
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has to monitor and regulate private tuition which has become a 65 billion rupee a year industry, State Minister of Higher Education, Suren Ragahavan said.

“The tuition industry has to be regulated and monitored,” Raghavan told reporters.. “The tuition industry has to be regulated, it has been reported that the industry earns 65 billion rupees an annum.”

“But in return what to the students get?  What are their (tuition teachers’) qualifications, some teachers teach beyond their subject, politics, vulgarism, ethnicity, interpretation of religion and videos are being circulated on social media.”
Parents in Sri Lanka are spending a lot of money for private education, due  to shortcomings in the state education system and limited slots in the universities.
Unlike the government system where the parents have no control over quality, in the case of private tuition they choose the best teachers or stop if they are not satisfied.
The best teachers get more students and can also charge higher fees, observers say.
Ragavan said mass class teachers earn millions. And they can be taxed.
“On average each mass tuition teacher earns 12 million rupees a month, but this goes unnoticed in tax,” Raghavan said.

“We will have a dialogue with the Tuition Teachers Association to see how they would like to be responsible citizens, do they have qualifications, license, emotional capacity, know about young adult psychology, hygiene, safety facilities,” Ragavan said.
“Most tuition teachers have got the benefit of free education and they are charging exorbitant prices for their students, with the minimum amount of facilities for students.
“Tuition teachers should get licenses and be enrolled in the tax system.
“Most of the teachers got the benefit of free education from the state and I hope they are responsible to pay off their taxes and assist our school children.”
Sri Lanka is trying to collect more taxes under ‘revenue based fiscal consolidation to support a large public sector, military, and plethora of minister and ministries. (Colombo/June21/2023)
